author: matthalloran8
title: Open Standards Library
description: Metadata standards are an important aspect of smart contract development, yet there is no easy way to use or design them.

f6_assessments.q0:
Yes, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge by developing a free open-source library of metadata standards that projects building on Cardano, technical or not, can benefit from. 

This is an exciting proposal as it focuses on reducing the barrier to developing by ensuring that all Cardano users can make use of the existing knowledge base across the ecosystem, when it comes to data. While teams will still be able to create and/or upload their own standards, others who may not want to create their own will benefit from a full library of options. This will likely appeal to a variety of different teams while simultaneously working towards a more standardized subset of metadata standards. 

The additional benefit of having the library on one site that is able to replace the standalone websites that exist for on-chain tasks. By having a one-stop-shop where groups can identify their appropriate standards and integrate them into their project will likely improve the developer ecosystem and provide additional functionality to Cardano. 

This proposal can also succeed in improving the connectedness of the ecosystem by providing a common taxonomy and lexicon for the community. In so doing, we can reduce the duplication and potential conflict of efforts.
f6_assessments.q1:
Yes, given the experience and plan presented, it is very likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully. 

From reading the proposal, it is very clear that the proposer is well educated and knowledgeable on the subject. The explanation of what they are trying to achieve, the need, and the solution are all very well laid out. 

The plan is to integrate the metadata standards library into their existing application "Vrooli". What is nice about this is that the Vrooli application is already up and running. Therefore, the integration into this application feels very feasible. It is also nice that the application will have both web-based and mobile accessibility, which will potentially further increase its use. 

The proposer provides supporting details of their experience and capability that imply they are up to the task and likely to deliver. Their credentials are well suited for this work, and although I may have liked a bit more granularity in the plan itself (beginning/end dates - in months so we can know when the project is expected to be delivered) the activities and timeline are sufficient.

The budget is clear, but my only critique here is that he should have splurged for a $20 bottle of celebratory champagne.
f6_assessments.q2:
Yes, the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and success of the proposal. 

As I like to say, any project that commits to being open source by default can give the community extra assurances that they will have an opportunity to audit the progress and success of the proposal. Cardano aims to be a global open source project and by instilling this approach from the outset, we only need to solve each of the major problems once, then everyone gets to benefit from that knowledge. 

The proposer also does a decent job at explaining their KPIs and success measures. By tracking the number of active users, standards created, and then number of votes across all standards, they hope to achieve thousands of developer hour saved and an increase rate of metadata standards development. I think the #s for each of the KPIs could also be success measures since those are what you are hoping to achieve. The nice part is that all of the data/analytics will be made free and available 24/7. 

For these reasons the community should be very confident in their ability to audit this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: I strongly agree that Vrooli addresses the challenges effectively as it will add facilitate the work of developers significantly. Vrooli is a feature packed metadata standard library that streamline the discovery of standards and allow anyone to input their own data into standards and an API. Later on Vrooli will have a smart contract execution feature and allow routines to be built on routines. It will be possible to share standards across DAOs. Even the possibility of downloading the entire library as the .csv file. Vrooli will help developers to receive feedback on standards early in the development. Instead of Cardano Improvement Proposal (CIP), the user can upload their own standards without having to write a formal proposal. It will save time & effort and lower barrier of entry. The key metrics and goals of proposal aligns very well with the challenge setting which is to create a positive developer experience so that the developers can focus on building the successful apps. The main risk of this proposal is on time but the proposer mitigate this by hosting all features on a website that will keep the development on track.
f6_assessments.q1: It is likely that the team is able to successfully implement the proposal. It shows very organized timeline of 16 weeks until its launch. Also the proposer gives the precise budget breakdown (enough to achive the goal). The project will be conducted by Matthew Halloran who is a full stack developer and a plutus pioneer. There could be future features that require funding from Catalyst again such as integration with DID and direct execution of smart contract.
f6_assessments.q2: The information is enough to audit the progress and success of this proposal. There is a clear roadmap with time horizon of 2 weeks to check the progress. The KPIs can be tracked (200 monthly active users, 50 standards created and 1000 votes cast in total) and the track result is real-time as Vrooli is on progressive web application. He has explained his targeted problem of developers in working with metadata standards and has created an open standards library which is easier for sharing and getting feedback for the development. Also the proposer could consider other public places where the community can be informed about the project other than its own domain of the project Vrooli

f6_assessments.q0: This project will help collect data from people in the street so that managers and developers can use it as their reference to build up their startup on the Cardano Blockchain successfully. This will help save a lot of time for developers to understand their customers and build up suitable apps to the market demand. To some extent, it will help improve developers' experience. However, it did not mention how it analyzes data and makes it useful for developers to use. This project seems to be simple and it did not emphasize how this will help develop the Cardano ecosystem. It should give the list of all questions so that people could see whether the data collected is mostly related to Cardano and this will encourage developers to build apps on Cardano as they got some information related to this blockchain. The proposal did mention one challenge when doing this project. That is related to Covid 19 and a solution for that was also given. Having said that, there may be more challenges so if the proposal would mention more things then it would be safer when executing this project.
f6_assessments.q1: The given plan was too general. The timeline is not clear. For example, the first week will start from what month. The description of what should be done and how things should be done should be mentioned in more detail. Currently everything seem to be not specific and easy to visualize. In terms of the budget breakdown, it provided the budget for each cost and how long it would take to use. It could be improved by mentioning how to calculate these costs whether they are measured by working hours, or working weeks or months. A short description about members operating this project was given, Having said that, it should highlight some relevant experience of these people to see why they are suitable for this project and how important they are to contribute to the whole success of the project. One good point here is that no one in the working team for this project works for another one. Therefore, all people involved will 100% focus on this project only so maybe it would be operated smoothly without worrying about overcapacity or something similar.
f6_assessments.q2: KPIs were set up clearly with specific numbers with the timeline to check them all. However,  apart from KPIs, it should include how to be achieved at each stage that goes in accordance with the timeline given in the plan so that people could see that at this stage whether everything is still going on track and it is still in good progress or not. The description of how to be considered a success of this project was kind of general. For example, it said that an increased rate of development for metadata standards would be considered a success of this project. However, how much the rate increases is good enough to evaluate, or it just if the rate increased then it would be considered that the project was launched successfully.

f6_assessments.q0: The main aim of this project is to build an open-source library that allows any user to search, share and contribute metadata standards. This library will act as a standards design reference resource for developers in building and choosing standards for their smart contracts. Thereby helping developers reduce the time and effort of building smart contracts, speeding up their entry and contribution to Cardano. With such a core idea, this project perfectly fits the key metric set by this Challenge. The library's architecture, operating structure, core functions, and user manual are easy to understand through clear descriptions and intuitive examples.
f6_assessments.q1: The definitions of the design framework and key functional nodes have been clarified, the project development roadmap is built so that it is easy to track the completion of the features and the overall structure of the library as mentioned. The timelines are appropriately allocated to ensure that the work is carried out according to the set schedule. The project implementation cost is allocated based on the working hours of the main developer of the project, the required remuneration is appropriate to the job characteristics, and the rest will be devoted to the necessary resources for project development. The direction of cash flow is clear and consistent with the project development plan. Although there is a link to the profile of this project lead Matt Halloran, the proponent should still include summaries of his work experience, technical skills, achievements, and expertise here.
f6_assessments.q2: In the project, two core pieces of information for the audit was provided to help improve the quality of the project and its reference value. The proponent has provided us with a link on which all work will be stored, including progress and results achieved. A reasonable audit roadmap has been developed, specific KPIs are provided that are consistent with the project's output and are ideal for success, and KPI measurement will be performed every month. In general, there are no obstacles for the community and experts when performing an audit of this project.

f6_assessments.q0: My congratulations go to the team for this great proposal, especially for the brilliant articulation of the context and the reasons we need to solve the different edges of this complex problem. According to the team, metadata standards are a vital component of smart contract development, yet they are difficult to utilize and construct. In order to address this problem, they tend to build an open-source library that allows anyone to search and build metadata standards by creating smart contracts, APIs, data, interfaces, and standards compatible and decentralized by utilizing visual building elements known as routine. I find this extremely interesting since not so many people are concerned about this problem. The objective and metrics of this proposal are aligned with those required by the challenge. Besides, there is a plus point that the team has given out a brief explanation for those unfamiliar with how metadata is used on Cardano. In conclusion, if the proposals made here were followed, it would be a major success not only for Cardano, but for the entire industry. The potential for expansion into other sectors is enormous.
f6_assessments.q1: The team possesses all of the experience required to perform this project and has provided a thorough bio for verification. The team has created a detailed plan. The plan for adopting this recommendation is obvious and sufficient in my opinion. I am unable to tell whether the desired amounts are appropriate because they vary greatly based on the local environment. However, I understand how they will be distributed, so the assignment appears to have been fulfilled in that regard.
f6_assessments.q2: There is sufficient data provided to audit the proposal's progress and success. The proposers presented a roadmap for their work, which allowed the community to track their progress. There are also concrete key performance indicators that might provide insight into project success. According to the proposal documentation, the proposers appear to be upfront about the project's progress, thus I anticipate frequent updates to the community.

f6_assessments.q0: The “Open Standards Library” project hits upon a frequent headache of any developer in that there are standards about formatting metadata are virtually nonexistent. Metadata, frequently in JSON format, allows for developers to put anything then need in it but when it comes time to search the metadata to find a particular piece of information things get tricky.  The project is to create the standards library and to implement this standard into their Vrooli Application (already done) which will allow users to build Smart Contracts with standardized meta data.  The impact of this, if it becomes a common standard, would greatly benefit the community, but sadly unless a developer is using their tool it will be a challenge to implement standards to the general public.  They will be requesting additional funding for ongoing work on the project.
f6_assessments.q1: They have already built the platform for creating Smart Contracts and are now working to implement standards for the meta data by adding a “standard builder”.  They will then autogenerate a form from the standards to enhance usability when building Smart Contracts. They have provided excellent details into the functionality of what they wish to build. The team has the skills to accomplish this task.  They have setout a very detailed timeline and budget to assure the project development is a success.  There is a risk factor that this is built on other projects but they assess this risk as only a small temporary delay to their timeline.
f6_assessments.q2: They plan to provide accountability why showing an increase in usage of their application and the number of standards created.  Their time lines are sufficiently defined to provide good accountability during development. Their solution will be of great benefit to anyone using their product and hopefully other Smart Contract developers will start to apply similar standards when using other tools.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is in alignment with the challenge brief of providing a supportive environment for developers by giving more accessibility to resources via a free library service for developers if they need to find metadata standards to use on their project. I view the idea as a convenience and time save for developers to have a library where they can search for specific standards they need in one platform instead of having it all scattered on the internet. I do however think that the challenge of getting this solution into use was not discussed enough. Presumably at the start, the library will be pretty much empty and it will depend on users using the standard builder feature to make standards to fill up the library. The method discussing how the proposer will get users on-board at the start was not touched on and I find there’s little incentive of using the service at the start, when there’s not much stuff in it. Regardless, I still think that the proposed solution can provide value to the Cardano developer ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team member claims to have the relevant experience and skills needed to implement this project, being a full-stack developer and a Plutus Pioneer, which suggests they have the relevant skills and knowledge to implement this project. However, there were no specific links or mentions explaining what projects they’ve worked on exactly and I’ll have to deduct points for that. 

The roadmap is laid out well detailing biweekly timelines and its respective milestones in the span of 16 weeks. The plan seems realistic to be completed in a timely manner. The budget has been broken down into identifiable items detailing the needed resources (e.g. server), total workhours, as well as requested hourly rate which is in the reasonable range for a full stack developer.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs chosen by the proposers are well defined providing a quantitative approach to evaluate the project’s performance, these includes “number of monthly active users”,  “number of standards created”, etc. These metrics can be used to evaluate the project’s performance in terms of the outreach, growth, and the quality of service the solution provided. Additionally, the metrics will be freely accessible (presumably via the website) at any moment making it transparent and easily trackable.

f6_assessments.q0:
Project offers ideas for building an open-source library that allows anyone to search and build metadata standards. This is a great idea and helps to discover a standards library to streamline the discovery of standards and allow anyone to contribute their own. It really is helpful, especially for those unfamiliar with how metadata is used on Cardano, here is a brief explanation. The development of new metadata standards increases the utility of the entire ecosystem and unlocks exciting new possibilities for the future. Therefore, the proposal is completely suitable for the challenge, and if successful, the proposal will help save a lot of time and mental effort, thus lowering the barrier of entry for smart contract development.

Users can design their own (completely new or based on existing standards), or be able to fill in the standard using an auto-generated form on the Vrooli application. It is a Progressive Web Application (PWA), so it can be downloaded as a mobile app. With these features, the proposal is an optimal solution to build smart contracts on the Cardano ecosystem in the simplest way.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal was made by Matt Halloran, a full-stack software developer with ten years of experience and also the 1st cohort Plutus Pioneer, with details updated on his personal website.

The project is executed according to detailed KPIs and clear time commitments. The budget is allocated mainly to the developer; however, with a large amount of time and work (16 consecutive weeks), I think it is a suitable cost for the value that the project brings. One thing I don't see mentioned in the description is a small budget for marketing - an element that helps promote the project to users
f6_assessments.q2: Project's success is visible through Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), which are automatically tracked and freely accessible in real-time. That is quantified in concrete numbers, that is: active users; standards created; votes cast; plus thousands of developer hours saved and development rates for metadata standards. In addition, the proposal is built on the proposal of the Fund6 "Interactive Guide created by the community". I believe that the project is completely grounded for implementation and practical application.
